results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 22-24.
results.creator_credit: Diane Sundin, SBS-TV, Mark Sanders, Ray Quint and Mandy Smith
results.brief_description: Episode 22, “Finding a place to live” examines the way that government agencies can assist people in selecting public or private accommodation. In “Voting” the Australian electoral system is explained and the importance of informed voting is debated. In “Making a new start” we are given a run-down on the new programs being introduced for unemployed people, particularly New Start and the Job Search Allowance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Diane Sundin, SBS-TV, Mark Sanders, Ray Quint and Mandy Smith

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 19-21.
results.creator_credit: Diane Sundin, SBS-TV, Ray Quint and Mark Sanders
results.brief_description: Episode 19, “Understanding superannuation” explains in everyday language the different types of superannuation policies available. In “Opening a bank account” the various types of bank and credit accounts are examined and appraised. The final episode on the tape, “Making statistics work for you”, shows how using mathematics in the workplace and at home need not be complicated but rather can make your work less disorganised.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 16-18.
results.creator_credit: Diane Sundin, SBS-TV, Mandy Smith and Ray Quint
results.brief_description: In episode 16 information is given on the workers’ rehabilitation program, as well as helpful advice on activities people can perform at home to alleviate repetitive strain injury. Episode 17 stresses the importance of effective occupational health and safety procedures in the workplace. And in “Solving problems at work”, examples are dramatised on how best to facilitate discussion between employees and employers.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 13-15.
results.creator_credit: Diane Sundin, SBS-TV, Karl McPhee and Mandy Smith
results.brief_description: In “Communicating change” issues of both coping with change in the workplace and change in personal relationships are addressed. Episode 14, “Planning for your retirement” answers some of the most frequent questions asked about superannuation. And in “Resolving conflicts” the Victorian Building Industries Agreement is examined as evidence of the importance of regular contact, negotiation and consultation between employers, trade unions and employees/members.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 10-12.
results.creator_credit: Diane Sundin, SBS-TV, Karl McPhee and Mark Sanders
results.brief_description: The first episode on this video is “Using electronic banking” and it explains the convenience and uses of modern ATMs (automatic teller machines). Episode eleven, “Retraining at work” contains a drama set in an iron factory to detail the advantages of retraining for both young and not-so-young workers. In “Using electricity safely” helpful hints and advice are given on how to protect oneself from electrocution, and the importance of ensuring your home or workplace has no faulty electrical wiring.

results.title: English at Work. - Eps. 1-3.
results.creator_credit: Diane Sundin, SBS-TV, Mark Sanders and Karl McPhee
results.brief_description: A series of videos examining the changing nature of work in contemporary Australian society and primarily aimed at audiences from non-English speaking backgrounds. In episode 1, “Improving your skills”, Rosa undertakes English classes to learn to read and write, and in the long term, to be able to take further courses to improve her skills. In “Finding a career” Trahn is encouraged by a work friend to learn English and find work similar to the job he left in Vietnam. In “Looking to the future” workers on a building site discuss the long-term importance of superannuation.

results.title: English at work
results.creator_credit: Christine Sammers, Kay Donovan and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
One of the greatest difficulties facing migrants arriving in Australia is the difficulty of acquiring English language skills. This video explores some of the innovative language courses being designed for work-places with a large number of non-English speaking background employees. The experiences of an older generation of migrants who received no English language training are contrasted with the experiences of more recent migrants who have found that English courses at work-sites offer a boost to their confidence at work. Apart from examining the benefits of English training at work, the video shows the conflicts arising between migrant and Australian-born workers, the latter often being initially resistant to the value of the courses.

results.brief_description: Designed to introduce migrants to aspects of Australian society and provide them with information and language required in specific contexts such as filing a tax return or buying a car.

results.title: English and Dutch colonization in the new world
results.brief_description: Reconstructs the beginnings of settlement in an English agricultural colony in Virginia, a Dutch trading colony in New York, and a Pilgrim colony in Massachusetts, and explains some of the basic motivations and patterns of colonisation.

results.title: England: home and beauty
results.brief_description: Domestic architecture, interior furnishing and the design of household objects were the subject of a protracted debate during the 1930’s. To increase Britain’s export sales, standards of design had to be raised, but there was no consensus for either of the two contenders-Bauhaus and Swedish inspired functionalism on the one hand or the jazzy modernistic Art Deco style on the other
